title: Fake Eyelash Kits Sourced From North Korea Put Cosmetics Firm in U.S. Crosshairs
summary: California company says it discovered the problem and reported it after a self-administered audit. A California cosmetics company agreed to pay about $1 million to settle allegations it violated U.S. sanctions regulations by importing fake eyelash kits from China-based suppliers that had sourced materials from North Korea.

title: Mr. President, Tear Down That Word
summary: Trump needs a way out of the shutdown. Meanwhile, Howard Schultz misjudges the country's direction.. NPR voice: This week in Advice for People Who Didn't Ask, we focus on two men of significant ambition who are making perplexing decisions.

title: Clash of the Billionaire Politicians
summary: Schultz's independent run makes more sense than Bloomberg's Democratic one.. Billionaire Michael Bloomberg lectured billionaire Howard Schultz Monday on the proper way to run for president. Third-party campaigns are a nice thought, explained Mr. Bloomberg, but the Starbucks baron is indulging in too grande-venti-trenta of an ambition: "There is no way an independent can win."

title: What to Do With Empty Churches
summary: A small and shrinking congregation often has the most beautiful religious architecture.. Wander any large U.S. city and you'll spot a serious mismatch. Majestic old houses of worship have only vestigial congregations. Without their endowments these cathedrals, chapels and synagogues couldn't keep the lights on.

title: 'Act Natural' Review: Don't Worry, They'll Survive
summary: How should you raise your children? Long ago, experts offered falsehood, myth and speculation. Modern parenting advice isn't much better.. Modern parenting literature portrays raising a child as difficult business. Make your own baby food or you risk raising a sugar addict. Letting a bored child play with your phone rather than sustainably sourced wooden blocks is an invitation to delinquency. Such advice is often premised on helping parents raise children "naturally," perhaps as children were parented at some ideal time in the past. But, notes Jennifer Traig-a book author, humorist and mother of two-in "Act Natural," the word "parenting" itself "only came into common usage about forty years ago, which I guess means parenting was invented after I was."

title: Two Centuries of Corporate Personhood
summary: Dartmouth won an important Supreme Court victory in 1819.. Jeff Clements, author of "Corporations Are Not People," delivered a lecture of the same title at Dartmouth a few years ago. One wonders if Mr. Clements appreciated the irony. It was in Dartmouth College v. Woodward, decided Feb. 2, 1819, that the U.S. Supreme Court affirmed the legal personhood of corporations as an essential principle of American law.

title: The U.N. Can Save Venezuela-Really
summary: Officially recognizing Guaidó would weaken Maduro's finances and grip on the military.. It's extraordinary how quickly the fortunes have turned against Venezuelan strongman Nicolás Maduro. His dream of a second presidential term was interrupted last week when the National Assembly declared his re-election invalid and legally removed him from office. Since Jan. 23, the U.S. and 20 other countries have recognized National Assembly leader Juan Guaidó as Venezuela's interim president, and the Trump administration has attempted to drain the Maduro regime's lifeblood by imposing sanctions on the state-run oil company. Yet Mr. Maduro is clinging to power, calling the military to his aid rather than going gently.

title: The State of the Union Without Artificial Sweeteners
summary: Trump will boast and brag. What if a president were appropriately grumpy?. Surely I am not the only one able to brook the lengthiest of delays in the delivery of this year's-or any other year's-State of the Union. The address has become a predictable bore. The president of either party emphasizes his accomplishments, diminishes or neglects to mention his defeats, and members of his party stand and applaud at every claptrap-I use the word in its original sense-while the opposing party remains seated in sullen disenchantment. The only item of possible interest in recent years has been whether Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg can remain awake.

title: Germany's Slowdown That Dare Not Speak Its Name
summary: The rise of the AfD and the threat of recession have so far failed to upset the country's complacency.. Berlin

title: The NFL Should Stop LIVing a LIII
summary: Does the Super Bowl really need Roman numerals?. Forget bad officiating and Deflategate. The National Football League has a bigger problem that afflicts us all-players, fans, gamblers, even advertisers. It's the title of the big game: Super Bowl LIII. It's high time the pigskin potentates abandoned their pretentious Roman numerals in favor of the familiar Arabic numbers.

title: Defense for 'El Chapo' Urges Jurors to Keep Open Mind
summary: In closing statement, Mexican drug lord's lawyer seeks to undermine credibility of cartel insiders who testified at trial. A lawyer for Joaquín "El Chapo" Guzmán Loera asked jurors in Brooklyn federal court to look past the Mexican drug lord's notoriety and acquit him of drug-trafficking charges, dismissing the government's witnesses over the past three months as liars.

title: Notre Dame Takes Down Catholic History
summary: Catholics against Columbus are covering murals that depict the explorer bringing their Catholic faith to the Americas.. Regarding Alejandro Bermudez's "Catholics Against Columbus" (Houses of Worship, Jan. 25): What's the matter with Father John Jenkins, president of the University of Notre Dame? By covering the Columbus murals at the school, he has waded into the progressive swamp which will sooner than later engulf him and the university. I hope there is a backlash to this action. Notre Dame should stick to what it does best: academics and football.

title: Free College Would Create Better Educated Citizens
summary: Free high school hasn't diminished the value of a high-school degree.. Regarding Dave Erchull's Jan. 24 letter responding to Jason Riley's ("Think College is Expensive? Wait Until It's Free," Upward Mobility, Jan. 16): I respectfully disagree. What is wrong with a cabdriver, or anyone else for that matter, wishing to be better educated? As important as it is, surely most would agree, there's more to life than just earning a living. To Mr. Erchull's point, presumably, free college would diminish the quality of a college degree. I'm not so sure. Has the availability of a free high-school education diminished the quality of a high-school diploma? In fact, I would argue the opposite, not to mention the benefits of a more-informed citizenry.

title: Congress Has Duty to Investigate Trump Hotel Lease
summary: Chairman Peter DeFazio on his probe of the Trump Organization.. Fred Barnes calls me "eager" to investigate President Trump regarding the Old Post Office building (OPO), where his hotel is leasing space from the federal government ("The Downside of Anti-Trump Rage," op-ed, Jan. 23).

title: Pope Should Address Bad Governments' Refugee Role
summary: The pope should admonish the leaders of countries generating refugees for not doing enough to counteract crime, poverty and hopelessness.. I appreciate Pope Francis' message about caring for our fellow human beings as they make great efforts to leave their countries and search for better lives ("In Panama, Pope Speaks Up for Migrants," World News, Jan. 25).

title: Even Government Lawyers Must Follow the Standards
summary: Every lawyer, government or private, is subject to rules of professional conduct which prohibit pursuing meritless litigation.. I agree with Judge Alex Kozinski that the government's limitless litigation budget poses a significant threat to private citizens and encourages never-ending litigation ("How a Pointless Lawsuit Took Off," op-ed, Jan., 25). Curiously, the judge fails to mention a very powerful tool in the judicial belt to curb such abuses. Every lawyer, government or private, is subject to rules of professional conduct which prohibit pursuing meritless litigation. I wonder whether anyone referred the obdurate U.S. attorneys to the governing disciplinary body?

title: Venezuela's Citgo Weighs Bankruptcy, Other Options
summary: Refining company seeks to protect operations amid a tussle between the Trump administration and Venezuela's government. The Trump administration's sanctions against Venezuela's oil sector are forcing the country's Citgo Petroleum Corp., one of the largest refiners in the U.S., to consider bankruptcy as a way to protect its operations amid the battle for political control in Caracas.

title: Knicks Trade Star Porzingis for... Nobody Knows
summary: Kristaps Porzingis is gone. But now the Knicks have enough money for two marquee free agents this summer. Will they land Kevin Durant?. The New York Knicks have not been a very good team in approximately forever. They have been plagued by chronic mismanagement and treated their fans to some terrible basketball in the five years since the NBA team in the league's biggest market made it to the playoffs. The only thing they had going for them was Kristaps Porzingis: the young superstar who, until late in the afternoon of a frigid winter day in the worst season in their history, they were planning to build around.

title: House Member Presses Boeing on China-Backed Satellite Deal
summary: McHenry requests details on what Boeing knew about Global IP's China links, probes whether deal violated U.S. export laws.

title: Venezuela Opposition Leader Outlines Plan to Revive Nation
summary: Juan Guaidó, recognized by Washington as the rightful leader, said he would sell state assets and invite private investment in the energy industry. CARACAS-Juan Guaidó, the 35-year-old opposition leader recognized by Washington as Venezuela's rightful leader, laid out a plan Thursday to reverse President Nicolás Maduro's economic polices and address Latin America's worst humanitarian crisis in decades.

title: Amazon: A Shiver Runs Through It
summary: Record sales and earnings show signs of deceleration-Amazon investors' greatest fear. Amazon.com just reported its best quarter ever and its worst quarter in years. That both are true speaks to the dichotomy inherent in evaluating what is-for now anyway-the world's most valuable company.

title: Banking With Beijing
summary: Malaysia is the latest country to rethink Belt and Road projects.. Eighteen months after a Chinese construction firm broke ground on Malaysia's 400-mile East Coast Rail Link, the $20 billion project has been cancelled. Or so it seemed on Saturday, before Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad contradicted his economics minister in saying that no decision has been made. But Mr. Mahathir has previously called these Chinese projects unfair, and he should stick to those instincts.

title: Senate Republicans Rebuff Trump on Syria Withdrawal Plan
summary: The GOP-controlled Senate advanced legislation opposing the president's decision to pull troops from Syria and Afghanistan. The GOP-controlled Senate advanced legislation on Thursday opposing President Trump's decision to withdraw troops from Syria and Afghanistan, the latest legislative rebuke to Mr. Trump's foreign policy from members of his own party.

title: Blurred Borders: Carlyle Raises €1.35 Billion for New Tech Fund
summary: Private-equity giant looks to invest more of its latest fund on both sides of the Atlantic. Carlyle Group LP has rounded up €1.35 billion ($1.55 billion) for its latest fund focused on investments in European technology businesses. But this time around, the firm predicts more of those companies will span both sides of the Atlantic.

title: Tool Company Claims IPS Worldwide 'Misappropriated' Millions
summary: Creditor Stanley Black & Decker is owed $41 million from the bankrupt freight-payment provider. Stanley Black & Decker Inc., owed an estimated $41 million by bankrupt freight-payment services provider IPS Worldwide LLC, says the company "misappropriated" its cash, according to recent court filing.

title: Vale in Talks on Payments to Brazil's Dam Disaster Victims
summary: The disaster has claimed at least 110 lives, with 238 more missing and feared dead. SÃO PAULO-Brazilian mining giant Vale SA hopes to sign a deal with the state of Minas Gerais soon so it can start paying damages to the victims of the collapse last week of a tailings dam owned by the company.

title: Nick Saban Wins Again in Baton Rouge-Over the IRS
summary: Alabama coach's Louisiana real estate deduction gets Judge's blessing. Alabama football coach Nick Saban racked up a win this month after all, prevailing over the Internal Revenue Service in court.

title: Secrets of Wealthy Women: Sex-Trafficking Survivor Rachel Lloyd on Founding a Nonprofit
summary: She tells host Veronica Dagher how she has made it her mission to lead women to a safe and successful future in the WSJ podcast. When she was just 13 years old, Rachel Lloyd dropped out of school to help support her alcoholic single mother pay the bills.

title: Dow Industrials Edge Lower on Sluggish Earnings
summary: Blue chips and S&P 500 finish January with strong gains. A trio of disappointing earnings reports pulled the Dow Jones Industrial Average slightly lower Thursday, though the blue-chip index still logged its strongest January performance since 1989.

title: Germany Weighs Purchase of 45 Boeing-Made F/A-18 Warplanes
summary: Possible deal would be win for Trump administration but surprise blow to Lockheed Martin. BERLIN-Germany is considering purchasing 45 Boeing Co. -made F/A-18 warplanes for its air force, German government officials said Thursday, in what would be a win for the Trump administration but a surprise blow to Boeing rival Lockheed Martin Corp.

title: GE: Not Good, but Good Enough
summary: GE shares rose as the company lagged analyst consensus but CEO Larry Culp sent a clear message that he has stopped the rot. General Electric Chief Executive Larry Culp kicked off the company's conference call with a telling reference to the best-seller "Good to Great."

title: San Francisco's Soda Health Warning Found Unconstitutional
summary: Judges rule that city's required wording on ads for sugary drinks violates First Amendment. A federal appeals court ruled a San Francisco ordinance requiring health warnings on advertising for sugary drinks violates the First Amendment, in a victory for national beverage makers whose products have come under increasing government scrutiny.

title: Facebook, Twitter Remove Accounts to Combat Foreign Misinformation
summary: Social-media giants say accounts originated in Iran, Venezuela. Facebook Inc. and Twitter Inc. said on Thursday that they removed hundreds of fake accounts from Iran and Venezuela spreading misinformation on their social-media platforms.

title: New Jersey Lawmakers Pass $15 Minimum-Wage Bill
summary: Increase to be phased in, with most workers eligible for top rate by 2024.

title: Con Ed Seeks Rate Increases for New York City-Area Customers
summary: Utility's residential gas customers would see the biggest jump in their monthly bills under the proposal. Consolidated Edison Inc. is seeking permission to raise electricity and gas rates in and near New York City, but the utility is likely to face pushback on the proposal and the level of increases it is seeking.

title: Lebanon Gets a Government Nine Months After Elections
summary: Wrangling between factions backed by Saudi Arabia and Iran have pushed country to brink of economic collapse. BEIRUT-Rival factions in Lebanon agreed Thursday to form a unity government nearly nine months after the elections, ending a political standoff that has pushed the country to the brink of economic collapse.

title: N.Y.C.'s Troubled Housing Authority to Go Under Federal Monitor
summary: Feds will pick new housing authority management as city commits to funding fixes. The New York City Housing Authority, operator of the largest public housing system in the U.S., will be given new management assigned by the federal government, and the city will have to commit to spending billions of dollars to fix its aging housing stock, according to a decision announced Thursday.

title: U.S. Weighs New Russia Sanctions Over Ukraine Sailors' Detention
summary: Russia is still holding two dozen Ukrainian sailors it detained in the Sea of Azov, heightening tensions. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration is considering new sanctions against Russia over its detention of 24 Ukrainian sailors seized in November, including penalties against Russian ships, the U.S. envoy to Ukraine said Thursday.

title: GE Cites Progress Toward Turnaround After Tough Year
summary: Power unit weighed on fourth-quarter results; conglomerate to pay $1.5 billion to settle subprime probe. General Electric Co. executives said they were making progress in turning around the troubled conglomerate, after the company reported another quarter of weak profits in its core power business and legacy problems in its GE Capital unit.

title: 'Russian Doll' Review: A Matter of Life and Death, and Death, and Death
summary: Natasha Lyonne stars as a woman who keeps dying during her birthday party only to find herself transported back again and again, alive, to the festivities.. Likability is an overrated virtue on television to judge by Nadia Volvokov (Natasha Lyonne), the hard-boiled hipster of "Russian Doll." Recreationally vulgar, a sufferer of absolutely no fools, and abrasive enough to send people scattering, she's also a woman resigned to the unsplendid eventualities of middle age in a city poised on the precipice of decadent collapse. She's kind of lovable. And people come to her birthday party. So how bad can she be?

title: 'The ABC Murders' Review: The Detective Has a Secret
summary: This Christie adaptation, starring John Malkovich, uncovers more of the back story of the least flamboyant, most downbeat Hercule Poirot we've ever met.. Hercule Poirot, the fussy, fastidious and not-French detective created by Agatha Christie, has provided a number of great actors a dignified way to serve up their inner ham: Albert Finney, Peter Ustinov, Ian Holm, Kenneth Branagh-even the sublime David Suchet-all threw understatement to the wind. And given how the Christie twists have wheedled their way into the mystery lover's mind, the question surrounding any new Poirot adaptation isn't really "whodunit." It's "who's overdone it?"

title: Do Bose's New Audio Sunglasses Live Up to the Hype?
summary: The audio giant's new smart shades pump high-quality beats into your ears without shoving plastic buds in them. NOTHING BEATS getting something free, except when it comes to earbuds. Though most smartphones come bundled with shoddy buds, 50% of those subpar sets never make it out of the box, according to tech researchers at the Diffusion Group. Instead, as per data analytics firm Statista, Americans who want to hear Kendrick Lamar and Chris Stapleton spent nearly $4 billion on finer headphones in 2018.

title: Scooter Startup Lime Is Raising $400 Million at $2 Billion Valuation
summary: GV, the venture capital arm of Google parent Alphabet, is expected to lead the latest round. Scooter startup Lime is raising $400 million at a $2 billion valuation in the latest funding round, according to a regulatory filing. This is a big boost to the ride-sharing electric-scooter sector that has seen sizeable investor interest despite questions about profitability and vandalism.

title: Afghan Leader Tells Trump Kabul Is Willing to Help Cut U.S. Troop Costs
summary: Ghani's letter to Trump signals concern about the effects of a hasty American troop withdrawal on security in Afghanistan. DUBAI-In an effort to keep U.S. military forces in Afghanistan, President Ashraf Ghani has told President Trump that the Kabul government is willing to discuss how to reduce the size and cost of maintaining America's military presence in the country.

title: Vintage Trains and Planes Converted Into Novel Restaurants and Bars
summary: From a 1900s caboose in Portland, Ore., to a 737 in central China, five vintage trains and planes transformed into unique restaurants and bars. WHEN THE TWA HOTEL opens this spring at John F. Kennedy International Airport, tipplers will find bar stools instead of passenger seats behind the cockpit of a parked 1958 TWA prop plane. But this won't be the first time a plane has been transformed into a pub. Among the growing number of aircraft and trains to be repurposed as bars or restaurants, these five are well worth boarding-no ticket required.

title: Stocks Post Best January in 30 Years
summary: Gains by banks and small caps helped lift the Dow and S&P 500 to their best starts since the 1980s. Banks and smaller companies propelled stocks to their best January in 30 years, a sign that investors are favoring sectors tied to the U.S. economy.

title: U.S. Government Bonds Extend Post-Fed Rally
summary: Data showing eurozone in 2018 grew at weakest pace in four years helped push investors toward safer assets. U.S. government-bond prices extended gains Thursday, as month-end buying and weak European economic data added to demand for Treasurys.

title: Polar Vortex Strains Systems; General Motors Halts Factories
summary: Deadly cold prompts factory closures in Midwest as frigid temperatures move east. Auto makers closed factories, airlines canceled more flights and gas utilities urged customers to turn down their thermostats as the Midwest continued to grapple Thursday with deadly Arctic temperatures.

title: 'Arctic': Acing the Ice
summary: After a plane crash, the lonely hero of Joe Penna's debut feature must choose between staying in the relative safety of the wreckage or venturing into a frozen landscape to look for help.. Back stories are the stuff of rich literature, but all too often in these overexplained times they're the bane of strong drama. In "Arctic" a pilot has crashed his single-engine plane in the middle of a snowy nowhere. If the film weren't as clean and uncluttered as it is, we might be told that his crash had complex antecedents. Maybe his mind was clouded by opioids after the loss of his newborn quintuplets to an incurable disease, he misread the coordinates on his charts and, in a mounting delirium of anxiety and grief, ran out of fuel. Instead, Joe Penna's fine debut feature, with Mads Mikkelsen in the only speaking role, tells us nothing about the man except his name-it's Overgård, according to a patch on his parka-and shows, entirely in the present tense, his desperate struggle to stay alive, and to save another life in the process.

title: 'Daughter of Mine': What Makes a Mother
summary: Laura Bispuri's Italian film questions the nature of maternity with a story about a child raised by her birth mother's neighbor.. A small movie set in coastal Sardinia, "Daughter of Mine"-in Italian with English subtitles-asks big questions and answers them fully, vividly and affectingly, without a trace of sentimentality. The most obvious question concerns the maternal bond: Who can claim it more persuasively, the birth mother or the woman who has raised the child? Two other questions, though, dominate a specific child's life as she approaches her 10th birthday: Who am I, and who should I be?

title: 'Miss Bala' Review: Misfire in Mexico
summary: The story of a young woman caught up in narco gang warfare in Tijuana is loaded with action cliches.. As entertainment calculations go, "Miss Bala" has a lot going for it-a large Hispanic-American audience may welcome an action adventure made mainly by and targeted at Hispanic-Americans, with a gun-toting heroine, Gloria, played by Gina Rodriguez. As entertainment, however, the film is calculation impure and simple. It's a box-ticking exercise in female jeopardy, survival and empowerment, oppressively efficient in its relentless way but unrelieved by emotional resonance.

title: Nobody Believes in Tom Brady. Or Something Like That.
summary: For motivation, a Super Bowl perennial tries on the underdog (or underdog-ish) mentality. Historically, Super Bowl week is a mockable target-a circus-like crush of media nonsense that mostly embarrasses everyone associated with it. But in 2019, how is it different than any other clown car pile-up in American public life? Is modern political coverage some sort of dignified enterprise when compared to football's? Turn on cable news-everyone is croaking away like caffeinated bullfrogs. Every machination of Washington, D.C., is breathlessly hyped like destruction's eve. Social media is a shoelace fire atop a tire fire atop a garbage fire.

title: U.S. Oil Prices Fall Amid Doubts Over China Trade Deal
summary: Crude prices reversed earlier gains on concerns of weaker global economy. • U.S. oil prices reversed earlier gains to end lower Thursday after President Trump said any U.S.-China trade deal may have to be postponed, which sparked concerns of a weaker global economy and reduced demand for oil.

title: Huawei Faces Deepening Scrutiny in Europe
summary: EU is latest authority to consider measures to address concerns about the Chinese telecommunications-equipment maker. The European Union is exploring ways to address security concerns about Huawei Technologies Co. and other Chinese telecommunications-equipment suppliers, EU officials said, a move that could effectively halt sales of Huawei gear in one of the company's most important markets.

title: Treasury to Sell $218 Billion in Debt
summary: U.S. Treasury Department's auctions next week will range from 18-day cash-management bills to 30-year bonds. The U.S. Treasury Department will auction $218 billion in securities next week. Details (all with minimum denominations of $100):

title: Net Neutrality Rollback Faces Legal Challenges Testing Trump Agenda
summary: Internet companies, consumer advocates and several states want to invalidate the Federal Communications Commission overturn of net neutrality. WASHINGTON-The conservative rollback of Obama-era net-neutrality rules faces its first major legal test Friday, when a federal court considers lawsuits brought by consumer advocates, internet companies and a group of Democratic-led states that oppose the deregulation.

title: Gold Extends Rally After Cautious Fed Comments
summary: Most-active Comex copper futures rose as investors hope a trade resolution will boost the outlook for global growth and commodity consumption. Gold prices surged again Thursday, supported for much of the day by a sliding dollar and falling Treasury yields after the Federal Reserve indicated late Wednesday it was done raising rates for now.

title: Albert Dunlap Compared Himself to Springsteen, Then Came the Fall
summary: Wall Street was sold on 'Chainsaw Al' until his turnaround at Sunbeam proved to be a mirage.

title: Trump Willing to Move Without Congress on Border Wall
summary: The president said the White House and congressional negotiators are no closer to an immigration deal. WASHINGTON-President Trump said Thursday that the White House and congressional negotiators were no closer to an immigration deal, five days after he agreed to end the partial government shutdown, and reiterated he is willing to act alone to build a wall on the southern border.

title: 'Ah, Wilderness!' Review: Comedy That Passes the No-Budget Test
summary: A stripped-down production of Eugene O'Neill's only mature full-length comedy shows that the playwright's work endures.. New York

title: Racist and Anti-Semitic Imagery Scrawled in Elite New York City School's Bathrooms
summary: Principal of Brooklyn Technical High School beefed up supervision of boys' bathrooms. The principal of one of New York City's top public schools, Brooklyn Technical High School, beefed up supervision of boys' bathrooms this week after finding racist and anti-Semitic imagery inside them, emails show.

title: Dozens of Advisers Face Claims of Overcharging for Mutual Funds
summary: More than 50 investment advisers face pressure to settle federal claims as part of SEC probe. More than 50 investment advisers are under pressure to settle federal claims they steered customers to higher-fee mutual funds over cheaper versions, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Blackstone, Apollo Hurt by Falling Markets in Fourth Quarter
summary: Blackstone also strikes first two deals by its new infrastructure fund. Private-equity firms Blackstone Group LP and Apollo Global Management LLC became the latest financial players whose earnings were hit by volatile markets in the fourth quarter, but their portfolios held up better than the broader market.

title: Why Federal Worker Jobless Claims Are Relatively Low
summary: One reason: Some employees would have been required to pay back the unemployment-benefits money. Although the government shutdown that just ended was the longest on record, far fewer federal employees filed unemployment claims than during shutdowns in 2013 and the mid-1990s.

title: Agency Attacked for Approving Workplace Regulation During Shutdown
summary: Democrats and employee-rights groups question the timing of a rule that eases workplace injury reporting requirements.

title: Electrolux Seeks Split in Two, to Restart Investment in Tennessee
summary: Company expects to spend $250 million in Springfield, while ceasing production at its facility in Memphis. Electrolux AB said Thursday that it is preparing to split in two, separating its professional-products and household-appliances businesses, while restarting its investment in its Springfield, Tenn., plant.

title: Thank the Fed for a Retro January Surge
summary: Risky investments are back after a bleak December, echoing what is known as the 'January effect'. What a January!

title: Tinder CEO Swipes Right on These Advisers
summary: Elie Seidman prioritizes the perspectives of good listeners and those whose career paths diverge from his. As boss of Match Group Inc.'s steamiest dating app, Tinder Inc., Elie Seidman says he invites criticism but doesn't act on every piece of advice he receives. He prefers feedback from people with whom he's worked closely so he knows how to interpret their suggestions. He also prioritizes counsel from people who are good listeners, a trait he thinks is undervalued in the C-suite, and people whose career paths diverge from his. "I've spent most of my work life in companies that are startups," he says, "but I'm interested in the perspective of people who have spent a lot of their life at very big organizations." Here, four trusted advisers:

title: Love, Grandma: How Grandparents Can Help Pay for College
summary: When grandparents own the '529,' there can be advantages. But don't run afoul of rules for aid consideration.. Readers wrote to us with questions about saving for college and tax-advantaged "529" accounts. We asked experts to help us answer them.

title: Intel's CEO Search Ends Where It Began: With the CFO
summary: Bob Swan named chief executive; Todd Underwood will serve as interim chief financial officer. Intel Corp. ended a seven-month search for a new leader by removing the interim title from CEO Bob Swan, calling on the longtime tech executive to solve thorny manufacturing problems at a time when demand for its once-hot data-center chips is cooling.

title: The Winter Salad Everyone Wants
summary: It's satisfying, a little spicy, and happens to be vegan. This recipe from New Orleans chef John Sinclair puts winter grapefruit, squash and radicchio to use in a dish that pleases everyone at the table. YOU COULD CALL it bar food. That's how chef John Sinclair describes the offerings at his two New Orleans bar-restaurants, Barrel Proof and Longway Tavern. But the term hardly seems equal to this salad of radicchio and arugula tossed with roasted squash, fennel, grapefruit and crunchy pistachios, Mr. Sinclair's first Slow Food Fast recipe.

title: Why Serious Cooks Are In Love With Frozen Food
summary: Revisit the supermarket's coolest aisle and hack into your freezer's full potential. These brrrilliant recipes for no-thaw pork chops, clam chowder and bhindi masala make an airtight case. I KNEW I WAS entering "a new life stage" when I recently found myself fantasizing about buying a second freezer. My interest in maximum cubic capacities and automatic defrost cycles was not precipitated by a craving for Hungryman dinners or initiation into a doomsday cult. Rather, as a recipe developer and my family's primary cook, I've come to regard my freezer as my most reliable wing man.

title: Charter Communications Shares Edge Up on Revenue Report
summary: Cable giant said it plans to decrease its capital expenditures by nearly $2 billion in 2019. Shares of Charter Communications Inc. soared on Thursday after revenue at the internet, cable and phone company came in ahead of expectations.

title: Emerging-Market Currencies Rise on Dovish Fed
summary: Expectations that U.S. rates won't rise tend to raise the attractiveness of emerging-market assets. Emerging-market currencies rallied Thursday, as investors reacted to a dovish pivot from the Federal Reserve.

title: Can I Wear Logos Without Them Wearing Me? An Investigation
summary: Fashion logos are back, but wearing them indiscriminately can hurt your personal brand. A smart woman's guide. I enjoy shopping alone, but I'm never truly alone. Inside my head, a chorus of critics-ranging from my accountant to Trinny and Susannah from the original British version of "What Not to Wear"-tends to weigh in on potential purchases. A few seasons back, it was my mother's voice that piped up as I stood in the downtown Manhattan Balenciaga store, transfixed by a preppy-ish denim tote emblazoned with a retro-looking logo. "How tacky!" she said. "You don't want to be a walking billboard." In my childhood, she'd barred me from wearing logos and, as an adult, I found them kind of distasteful myself. Yet recently I've been inexplicably drawn to conspicuously branded fashion: shoes with Chanel's interlocking Cs, Supreme baseball caps, Gucci sweaters. Why, as a rational, frugal, navy-clad mom myself, am I suddenly struck with an embarrassing case of logo fever?

title: We Found the Perfect Women's Work Bags
summary: After an intensive search and interviews with dozens of women, we've landed on 10 do-it-all solutions that marry function with elegance-and out-perform any man's briefcase. SCENE: A PACKED New York City subway train, headed toward midtown in morning rush hour. Professional women, nearly all scanning smartphones, balance bags on their knees, in the crook of their arms, on their shoulders, or, cringingly, between their shoes on the germy floor. I clock a weathered Goyard purse, a boxy Kate Spade bag, a structured Prada "Saffiano Executive Tote Bag," a cotton tote printed with the name of an art fair. In them? Judging from conversations I've had with dozens of women, the contents could include anything from gym clothes to flat shoes to legal briefs to laptops to lunches to breast pumps. A "work bag" is arguably the most important fashion investment women can make-able to serve as a mobile home office, to make or break an outfit.

title: A Solar-Powered Dream Home, With the Electric Vehicle to Match
summary: Dan Neil lays out plans for his perfect home, complete with solar panels and a 'honking' battery to store solar energy for fueling an EV-at zero cents per mile. No. Don't the batteries just wind up in landfills? Oy, no. Aren't EVs more expensive? Not the one I'm buying.

title: Super Bowl Sunday Is Bigger Than Football
summary: In an age of fragmentation, one TV event still brings the whole country together. A century from now, professional football may still be going strong, or it may have disappeared like chariot racing and jousting. Whatever the case, on that first February Sunday of 2119, it's likely that tens of millions of Americans will get together with family and friends. They'll drink. They'll eat salty foods and fatty foods. They'll drink some more, and they'll plop down on couches to celebrate Super Bowl CLIII-even if the NFL is long gone.

title: Aristotle's Pursuit of Happiness
summary: The ideas of the Greek philosopher can still help us create better lives and communities. The inalienable right to pursue it, along with life and liberty, was enshrined by Thomas Jefferson in the Declaration of Independence.

title: To Make Stripes Feel Fresh, Layer Them Wantonly
summary: Take a cue from the women's resort collections and pile on striated pieces from basic to brash. ONCE UPON A time, wearing stripes could get you killed. According to medieval records, at least one Frenchman-a cobbler-was executed as punishment for his striped garb in 1310. Back then, the pattern was widely associated with the devil and other unsavory characters like prostitutes, prisoners and clowns. But by the end of the 18th century, stripes had shed their stigma. They were embraced by the upper class and later, in the 19th century, were adopted by the French Navy in the form of the iconic Breton-striped top. Coco Chanel introduced mariner-inspired stripes into the high-fashion lexicon, and stripes have since taken plenty of turns on the catwalk.

Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn, N.Y., made their final pitch to jurors to find Joaquín "El Chapo" Guzmán Loera guilty of smuggling tons of illegal drugs to the U.S., after calling more than 50 witnesses at trial to testify against the infamous Mexican drug lord.

title: High-Wire Audit Looms as Regulators Scrutinize KPMG and GE
summary: Year-end audits are usually routine affairs, but with GE under investigation and KPMG under scrutiny from regulators, this one could cause fireworks. Accounting giant KPMG LLP has been blessing the books of General Electric Co. for 110 years, but the audit currently under way holds significant risks for both companies.

title: Microsoft's Cloud Should Shine Past PCs Pain
summary: PC slump hurts, but investors should keep eye on growing cloud prize. Microsoft got the important things right in its most recent quarter. But as one of the world's most valuable companies now, the software giant has lost the benefit of wiggle room.

title: The Fed's Mysterious Pause
summary: If the Federal Reserve is signaling a halt to rate increases, it could mean officials view the economy as fundamentally fragile. The Federal Reserve's monetary tightening hasn't just paused; it may be over.

title: VA Issues New Rules Expanding Access to Private Care
summary: Move is seen costing billions and igniting debate over effect on veterans' public services. WASHINGTON-The Department of Veterans Affairs announced new rules greatly expanding the amount of medical care provided to military veterans through the private sector, potentially costing billions of dollars and fueling debate over the privatization of the health services under the Trump administration.
